721487f-a.text:
Madison Square, looking northeast from the corner of Broadway and 23rd Street. Madison Square Garden is about three years old. The first Diana of St. Gaudens was removed from the tower the preceding September to be sent to Chicago for the World's Fair, where she was destined to remain until she was destroyed by fire, a few years later. Shortly after this photograph was made the Second Diana (also by St. Gaudens), somewhat smaller than the first, was placed on the tower and remained there until May 26, 1925, when she was removed for the demolition of the building.
The house on the N.E. corner of 25th Street and Madison Avenue will be demolished about 1898. By 1920 the houses on Madison Avenue between 24th and 25th Streets will all be replaced by office buildings. At the S.E. corner of Madison and 24th Street, where the Metropolitan clock tower will rise in 1907, we see the old Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, built in 1854. In the right foreground is the Hotel Bartholdi.
Note the brand new Metropolitan Life building at 23rd Street and Madison Avenue, the first of the buildings which will ultimately take up the whole block.
1893.
Brown Brothers, Photographers.

731189f-a.title: Celebrations - Parades - Municipal events - The Dewey Arch.
731189f-a.text:
Celebrations, Parades and Municipal Events: The Dewey Arch at Fifth Avenue and 24th Street, viewed northward up the Avenue. To the right is Madison Square
Park.
198
Copyright 1899
J. S. Johnston
Gift of Urbrock Collection

721505f-a.text:
Madison Square, looking N.E. from Broadway and 23rd Street, showing the snow being cleared away. The tower is that of Madison Square Garden (1889-1925). The white marble Appellate Division Supreme Court building (about 1898), on the northeast corner of Madison Avenue and 25th Street, is visible through the trees.
About 1903-1904.
Ewing Galloway, Photographer.

711655f-a.text: Where Broadway, Fifth Ave. and 23rd Street cross is the Fuller Bldg. but popularly known as the Flatiron Bldg. due to its shape.  The term "23 Skidoo" allegedly originated here, folks hanging out on corner being chased by beat cops. Picture was probably taken from the old MetLife Bldg. at corner of 23d and Madison.

717348f-a.text:
Broadway,east side, south across 23rd Street, as photographed from Fifth Avenue. At the left ia an easterly view on the south side of East 23rd Street. The corner structure is the former Hotel Bartholdi. Madison Square Park is at the left margin and only partially appears.
July 18, 1939
P. L. Sperr

711651f-a.text:
East 23rd Street, east from Broadway, showing W.P.A. track removal project under way. On the left appears a portion of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Co. building.
September 2, 1936

W.P.A. Photo
Federal Art Project

731175f-a.title: Celebrations - Parades - Municipal events - Decoration Day Parade.
731175f-a.text:
Celebrations, Parades and Municipal Events. The Decoration Day Parade of May 30, 1894 showing the old Guard of the N.G.S.N.Y. at Madison Square. This photo appears on page 698 of the June 16,
1894 issue of the Illustrated American: Vol. 15.
The photographer is viewing southward on Fifth Avenue from a point near 25th Street and shows the group, the reviewing stand, the park and the Hotel Barthold. The latter is at the S.E. corner
of Broadway and E. 23rd Street.
May 30, 1894
The Illustrated American
